Hospital Mobile Notary - Tier 1

Mobile Notary for Providence Holy Cross Medical Center (Mission Hills)

When you need a notary at Providence Holy Cross Medical Center in Mission Hills, we come directly to the hospital so you do not have to worry about travel or delays. We regularly visit patients and families here to notarize urgent medical and estate documents right at the bedside.

Located just minutes from our Granada Hills office. Standard hospital visit starts at $195. Laptop and printer available for on-site document generation.

Call/Text (213) 933-2507 Book Hospital Visit
About Providence Holy Cross Medical Center

Bedside notary visits in Mission Hills

Providence Holy Cross Medical Center is a major hospital serving the San Fernando Valley, located at 15031 Rinaldi Street in Mission Hills. The facility includes a Level II trauma center, cardiac care, maternity services, and a wide range of inpatient units. Families and patients here often need important documents notarized quickly without leaving the hospital. We provide mobile notary visits directly to the facility, helping you complete medical and legal paperwork so treatment, discharge, or family decisions are not delayed.

As one of our Tier 1 (nearby) hospitals, Providence Holy Cross is just a short drive from our Granada Hills base, which means we can often respond quickly for same-day or next-day appointments.

How our visits at Providence Holy Cross work

What to expect when you book

We coordinate with you by phone or text to confirm the patient's legal name, room number, and the documents that need notarization. When we arrive, we check in at the front desk or security, follow hospital visitor procedures, and then meet you in the patient room or a designated family area.

Our goal is to keep the visit calm, efficient, and respectful of doctors and nurses who may need access to the patient. If the patient is in the ICU, undergoing tests, or has visitor restrictions, let us know ahead of time so we can plan accordingly.

Providence Holy Cross has a parking structure and visitor check-in process, so we build extra time into the visit for access and walking to your room. When you contact us, we will provide an arrival window so you know when to expect us.

Common documents we notarize at Providence Holy Cross

Medical, financial, and estate documents

Many families call from Providence Holy Cross when time and mobility are limited. Typical documents include:

  • Advance healthcare directives and living wills
  • Medical and durable powers of attorney
  • HIPAA authorization and medical records release forms
  • Wills, trust documents, and related estate forms
  • Financial powers of attorney and insurance or benefit forms that require notarization
  • Facility admission, transfer, or discharge paperwork

If you are not sure whether your form needs to be notarized, you can text us a clear photo in advance so we can review the notary section.

On-site document generation

Laptop and portable printer at Providence Holy Cross

If you need a power of attorney, healthcare directive, or other form but do not have it ready, you can use my equipment and Rocket Lawyer access to create the document during our appointment. This service includes use of my laptop, portable printer, internet connection, and platform access. You choose which documents to create; I provide the hardware and administrative help to get the paperwork ready.

Pricing at Providence Holy Cross (Tier 1)

  • Standard hospital visit: $195 (notarization of documents you bring)
  • Hospital visit with laptop and printer: $245 (includes 1 generated document)
  • Each additional document generated: +$50 per document
Important: I am a commissioned notary public, not an attorney. I do not provide legal advice, recommend specific documents, or explain your legal rights. Any help I provide with Rocket Lawyer or similar services is strictly administrative - using my laptop, printer, internet connection, and platform access to help you generate, print, and organize the forms you choose so they are ready to sign and notarize. For legal questions or to decide which documents are appropriate for your situation, please consult a licensed attorney.
Preparing for your appointment

What to have ready at Providence Holy Cross

To keep your visit smooth, please have:

  • A valid, government-issued photo ID for each signer (driver license, state ID, passport, or other accepted identification)
  • All pages of the documents printed and ready, not just the signature page (unless using our laptop/printer service)
  • Any required witnesses who are not named in the document and who meet the hospital's visitor rules

If the patient has limited mobility or is unable to sign in their usual way, let us know beforehand so we can discuss acceptable options under California notary law.

If ID is at home, we recommend having a family member bring it to the hospital before the appointment. In some cases, credible witnesses may be an option; we will discuss this with you in advance based on California law.

Frequently asked questions

Mobile notary FAQ for Providence Holy Cross

How quickly can you get to Providence Holy Cross Medical Center?

Because Holy Cross is one of our closest hospitals, we can often arrive within 1-2 hours for urgent requests during business hours, or schedule a same-day appointment when our calendar allows. For non-urgent needs, we typically offer next-day availability. Traffic on the 118 and 405 can affect timing, so we always confirm a specific arrival window when you book.

Can you notarize in the ICU or trauma unit at Holy Cross?

Yes, we can visit patients in the ICU, trauma unit, or other restricted areas as long as the hospital allows visitors and the patient is alert enough to understand and sign the documents. We recommend coordinating with the nursing staff to find a time when the patient is awake and not scheduled for procedures. Some units have specific visiting hours or require staff approval before we can enter.

Where do you park when visiting Providence Holy Cross?

Holy Cross has a multi-level parking structure near the main entrance off Rinaldi Street. We factor parking and walking time into our arrival estimate. If you are in a unit far from the main entrance, let us know so we can plan accordingly and text you when we are close.

What if the patient cannot hold a pen or sign their name?

California law allows for signature by mark (such as an "X") if the signer cannot write their full name, as long as certain witness requirements are met. In some cases, a signature by proxy may be possible, where another person signs on behalf of the signer at their direction. We will discuss the options with you before the appointment based on the patient's condition and the type of document.

Can hospital social workers or nurses witness the documents?

It depends on the document. Some forms allow hospital staff to serve as witnesses, while others require independent witnesses who are not employees of the facility or named in the document. Healthcare directives in California have specific witness rules. We will let you know what is required when you describe your documents, and you can arrange for family members or friends to be present if independent witnesses are needed.

What if the patient is discharged before you arrive?

Hospital situations change quickly. If the patient is discharged or moved before our scheduled arrival, contact us as soon as possible. We can often redirect to a home, rehab facility, or other location. If we are already en route and the appointment cannot proceed, we will work with you on rescheduling or adjusting the visit.

Schedule a visit

Book a mobile notary at Providence Holy Cross

To schedule a mobile notary at Providence Holy Cross Medical Center in Mission Hills, call or text us at (213) 933-2507, or request an appointment online. If your situation is urgent, let us know it is a hospital signing so we can prioritize your call and confirm the fastest available time.

We understand that hospital situations can change suddenly, and we do our best to accommodate last-minute schedule shifts, room changes, or early discharges.
